docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) released its latest report on the state of the world's species. It makes for gloomy reading. Although there have been a few triumphs - species increasing their numbers thanks to conservation efforts - the general picture is one of decline. A quarter of all mammal species are now endangered, mostly because their habitat is disappearing. But of all the mammals now on the endangered list, from the fishing cat to the Caspian seal, the most startling is the Tasmanian devil.
docs.abstract: Tasmanian devils might be facing extinction, and the cause is unusual and disturbing: an infectious cancer.
docs.snippet: Tasmanian devils might be facing extinction, and the cause is unusual and disturbing: an infectious cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: For a while now, nearly a dozen Senate races have captured our attention as the Democrats battle mightily to expand their thin majority in a year that would seem to favor them. First, they enjoyed an early fund-raising advantage and now the economic downturn seems to have ensnared even some surefire G.O.P. incumbent seats. On the other side, the Republicans aren't surrendering without a fight and are poised, according to some reports, with new cash infusions in the closing weeks.

headline.main: Senate Races Through a TV Lens

docs.abstract: Watching the candidates' commercials play out on your screens.
docs.snippet: Watching the candidates' commercials play out on your screens.

docs.lead_paragraph: This week's guest blogger is Bonnie Fuller, C.E.O. of Bonnie Fuller Media. Most recently, Fuller served as vice president and chief editorial director of American Media (Star, Shape, Men's Fitness, Natural Health and Fit Pregnancy) and was previously editor in chief of US Weekly, Glamour, Cosmopolitan, Marie Claire, YM and FLARE magazines. E-mail her at info@bonniefuller.com or follow her on Twitter here. Read previous Bonnie Fuller posts.

docs.lead_paragraph: The measures that South Dakota, Colorado and California have taken to end or limit abortion rights have much larger implications.

headline.main: Abortion Rights on the Ballot, Again
headline.print_headline: Abortion Rights on the Ballot, Again

docs.snippet: The measures that South Dakota, Colorado and California have taken to end or limit abortion rights have much larger implications.

docs.lead_paragraph: Once again this year, opponents of women's reproductive rights have managed to get initiatives aimed at ending or limiting abortion rights on ballots -- in South Dakota, Colorado and California. These measures, which violate women's privacy and threaten their health, have implications far beyond those states. If voters approve them, they will become a weapon in the right-wing campaign to overturn Roe v Wade. The South Dakota initiative is a near twin of the sweeping abortion ban handily rejected by South Dakota voters just two years ago. To make the ban seem less harsh, its backers have included language purporting to make exceptions for incest, rape or the life and health of the mother. But no one should be fooled. The exceptions were drafted to make it nearly impossible to get an abortion, even during the first trimester of pregnancy.

headline.main: Abortion Rights on the Ballot, Again

docs.abstract: Editorial scores anti-abortion ballot measures in South Dakota, Colorado and California, arguing that if approved, they would threaten women's health and privacy become weapon in campaign to overturn Roe v Wade

docs.lead_paragraph: Jets Coach Eric Mangini spent Friday morning at the hospital as his wife, Julie, delivered the couple's third son. Football pundits will have fun with the child's middle name - Brett - because not only was Zack Brett Mangini born in the year his father traded for quarterback Brett Favre, but they also now share the same birthday: Oct. 10.

headline.main: Mangini Gives Son Middle Name in Honor of Favre

docs.abstract: Eric Mangini celebrated the birth of his third son and chose the middle name Brett.
docs.snippet: Eric Mangini celebrated the birth of his third son and chose the middle name Brett.
